awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Institutional capacity as an organizational challenge: a field experiment in Pakistan
awd_abstract_narration:
Abstract Vyborny

Collaborative Research: Institutional Capacity as an Organizational Challenge: A Field Experiment

Efficient management of organizations---businesses, governments or non-profits--is central to economic growth and development.  Although there have been some studies of organizational efficiency in businesses, few have studied organizational efficiency in the public and non-governmental sectors---sectors that are becoming increasingly large shares of modern economies.  This research will use a unique field experiment, involving a large donor organization and over 800 recipient community organizations, to study the efficiency in large, multitiered and complex organizations with emphasis on how information flowing through the organization is used, and how to effectively incentivize agents to achieve the organization's goals.  This research will seek to answer three major questions: (i) can a transparent self-reporting tool and non-monetary incentive scheme motivate community organizations to achieve their goals; (ii) how do parts of a large complex organization respond to and use new information they receive; and (iii) how does the response to new information depend on the characteristics of the organization? The results of this research will lead to improvement in the performance of large, complex organizations generally.  Efficiency in these organizations will improve the performance of economies worldwide. 

Large organizations face challenges in managing information, setting incentives and delegating decision-making power to the relevant personnel. Existing empirical work investigate incentive problems in private organizations. However, limited attention has been paid to the performance of large non-profit and government organizations. This project will use a unique field experiment to address three issues---information and communication within organizations, divergent preferences within organizations, and performance of non-government organizations. The experimental design will allow the PIs to test three main ideas: (i) Can community organizations be incentivized through self-reporting and non-financial rewards to improve their performance; (ii) How does each part of a large, complex organization respond to new information on performance indicators; (iii) Do the responses of management and workers to the receipt of new information and incentives depend on organizational characteristics of the organization, communication costs between parts of the organization, and decentralization of decision making authority?  To answer the first question, over 800 recipient community organizations will be surveyed and then randomized into different self-reporting schemes using a two-by-two factorial design with controls.  This design allows the PIs to test for the impact of self-reporting on service delivery or governance. To answer the second and third questions, the PIs will carry out a novel revealed-preference ranking experiment involving both junior and senior management staff members. The results of this research will strengthen our understanding of the determinants of efficiency in organizations and in the process, contribute to increased efficiency of economies worldwide.

Background

 

This study takes a major step in understanding the role of organizational and management issues in economic performance. An issue of immense important yet have been unaddressed in the empirical literature.

 

A nascent literature tests the role of information transmission in changing the behaviour of senior decision-makers. To the researchers' knowledge, this study is the first experiment to address the cost of communication between multiple points throughout a complex, multi-tier organizational hierarchy.

 

Different members of an organization typically have different ideas and preferences about the organization's objectives. To the researchers’ knowledge, this is the first empirical study to map how preferences about the organization's objectives differ across multiple nodes within an organization hierarchy, and affect organizational effectiveness.

 

 

Setting

 

The setting we study is the Pakistan Poverty Alleviation Fund (PPAF) funded by the Government of Pakistan, the World Bank, and a number of bilateral aid agencies. This agency channels some of its funding through a second tier donor, the Program Office (PO), to local NGOs in communities across Pakistan.  We conducted a randomized experiment to test the impact of different factors on the performance of the local NGOs.

 

.

 

 

Design

 

The experiment involved a large donor organization (PPAF) and over 800 local NGOs. We tested:

 

1. Whether community organizations can be incentivized to improve their performance through
            a. Systematic self-assessment and reporting of defined Key Performance Indicators (KPIs)
            b. A transparent non-financial rewards scheme based on these KPIs;

2. How each part of a large, complex organization (the donor) responds to new information on performance (of recipient organizations) on the KPIs

 

 

 

 

 

 

NGO Component

 

We randomized 836 NGOs into different self-reporting schemes.  We use a two-by-two design with controls:  

 

Table 1: Experimental Design

 

 

KPI Scorecard

 

Service delivery

Governance

Self-reporting

119 NGOs

Control

360 NGOs

Ceremonies by random draw

 

 

 

Treatment NGOs were required to report once every six months on a scorecard of four KPIs. We measure performance of NGOs on two dimensions:

 

(i)             Governance and Inclusion via active participation of men and women in the Executive Body and General Body of the NGOs

(ii)            Service Delivery by NGOs in various sectors including health, education, agriculture and others.

 

In order to avoid misreporting, all NGOs in treatment group were informed at the beginning of the experiment about the chance of being verified after scorecard submission.

 

 

Donor Component

 

We run a revealed-preference ranking experiment at every node in the organizational hierarchy of the donor organizations. This includes the management officers, to whom they report and the first-tier donor (PPAF) units which are involved in the management of NGO grant programming, and PPAF's senior management.

 

Our team conducts an online web based survey with each designated official from each relevant organizational node. The exercise is conducted through screen sharing on Zoom. In each round, the official is provided a different set of indicators, related to a different group of NGOs. They are required to rank a list of NGOs, based on “which of these NGOs is, in your opinion, is best serving its community”. The activity is framed as a means for the respondents to give their input into the assessment of NGOs. Some of the Officials’ assessments is shared with their supervisors and subordinates, under each official’s own name. Officials are told this before they begin their ranking exercise. In this way, officials’ effort and reporting behaviour is directly incentivized.

 

 

Status of Survey

 

For the NGO component, the data collection has been completed. The research team is currently working on data analysis and will produce multiple academic and policy outputs. For the Donor component, the data collection is ongoing. Currently, the team has completed a significant number of surveys with the junior most node in the organizational hierarchy. After completing this phase, we will move one node above. The data collection for the Donor component will be completed by summer 2023. We anticipate issuing a working paper on each component in 2023.

 

 

Conclusion

 

This study helps understand what makes some NGOs more successful than others, and how to support and encourage their achievements in a more hands-off way using non-financial incentives such that these organisations improve service delivery and broaden inclusion. These insights play a pivotal role in helping PPAF to find effective ways of supporting and guiding these organisations without increasing their dependence on PPAF.

 

Improving monitoring and information sharing systems is a high priority for the implementing partners, which manage a large fraction of all the finance in Pakistan for rural development projects. This project provides a source of rich panel data on non-governmental organizations, local government and the provision of local public goods and services, issues of particular interest for researchers working on Pakistan.
